description: From Middle French guttural, from New Latin gutturālis, from Latin guttur (“throat”) + -ālis.

adjectives.description: guttural (comparative more guttural, superlative most guttural)

examples: Arabic is considered a very guttural language, with many harsh consonants.

entries.meaning: (phonetics) having a place of articulation towards the back of the mouth; in modern use, uvular, pharyngeal, or glottal; in earlier or non-technical use, also including velar.
(medicine, anatomy) Of, relating to, or connected to the throat.
examples: guttural duct of the ear;   guttural pouch infection

entries.meaning: A harsh and throaty spoken sound
